2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Overarching goal
      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value

        FinalAction

          Answer: Alice Lewis's prefered action is to suggest going to The Crooked Billet.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?

          Jack Taylor: 0.7
          Jacob Walker: 0.7
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to find a pub nearby.
          Question: What action Alice Lewis should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alice Lewis MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alice Lewis can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alice Lewis would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to a pub nearby.

They are also aware of the following:The staff are knowledgeable about their drinks and always happy to recommend something new.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
    Active player

      Name

          Key

        • Sensations and feelings
          Queries
        • level of hunger, level of thirst, level of fatigue, level of pain, level of loneliness
          State
        • Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is enjoying a pleasant afternoon in the park with friends.

      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a sociable and outgoing person who enjoys spending time with friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00]
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he orchestrated a school play, casting himself as the charismatic lead. He spent weeks rehearsing, ensuring every line dripped with charm and every gesture exuded confidence. The thunderous applause at the curtain call fueled his belief that he was destined for greatness.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Duke of York. They are also aware of the following:A dog-friendly pub with a spacious beer garden.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and outgoing person who enjoys spending time with friends.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and outgoing person who enjoys spending time with friends.

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.

However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have.           Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones is spending time with friends in a park and deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later that evening.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest The Duke of York as the place to watch the game; he could agree with Alice Lewis or Alexander White's suggestion of The Crooked Billet; or he could suggest a different pub altogether.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Duke of York as the place to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he found himself alone in the library, surrounded by towering shelves of books. He stumbled upon a tattered copy of Dostoevsky's "Notes from Underground," and as he read the words, he felt a strange kinship with the unnamed narrator, recognizing a reflection of his own hidden angst and alienation. The book became his secret companion, a source of solace and understanding in a world that seemed to misunderstand him.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Overarching goal
      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Alexander White should do now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: What action Alexander White should do now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Duke of York.
          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alexander White would prefered now?
          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to try to convince the others to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Jack Taylor: 0.8
          Alice Lewis: 0.7
          Jacob Walker: 0.7
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alexander White) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York.
          Question: What action Alexander White should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alexander White MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alexander White can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Duke of York.

      • Question: How credible the counterparts are?

          Memory
        • [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns seen in observations.
          Answer: Alexander White suggests The Crooked Billet for watching the Andorra versus Portugal game because of its beer and screens. Jacob Walker prefers The Duke of York, citing its atmosphere and large screens. William Jones agrees with Jacob Walker, also praising The Duke of York's atmosphere and screens. Jack Taylor prefers staying at Victoria Park but is open to finding a nearby pub later.

Jack Taylor prefers staying at Victoria Park but is open to finding a nearby pub later.

          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to try to convince the others to go to The Crooked Billet.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
      Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
    Active player

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, picnicking in the park and watching football games at The Duke of York pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Duke of York.

William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, picnicking in the park and watching football games at The Duke of York pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Duke of York.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Answer: William Jones enjoys spending time with friends, picnicking, and watching football.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
      Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
      Context for action selection and components
      • Overarching goal
      • Overarching goal
          Key
        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
        FinalAction
      • Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and join the group at Victoria Park.
          Chain of thought
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Jack Taylor would prefered now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's prefered action is to join his friends at Victoria Park.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Alexander White: 0.6
          Alice Lewis: 0.7
          Jacob Walker: 0.8
          William Jones: 0.7
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to join the group at Victoria Park.
          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Jack Taylor MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Jack Taylor can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and join the group at Victoria Park.

Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. None of Jack Taylor's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Mind if I join you all at The Duke of York?
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Mind if I join you all at The Duke of York?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
      Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?

        • Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York.
          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          Observation: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker are lounging. The group is deciding where to watch the Luxembourg versus Israel game, and they have settled on The Duke of York. Jack Taylor wants to join them.
          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could try to convince the group to go to The Crooked Billet instead of The Duke of York.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game, guys, come on!"
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game, guys, come on!"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
      Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
      Alice Lewis -- "Mind if I join you all at The Duke of York?


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game, guys, come on!"

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and outgoing person who enjoys spending time with friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at a park and will be joining them later at a pub called The Duke of York to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, but he is feeling a bit disappointed because not all of his friends will be at the pub to watch the game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of his friends who are there.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game, guys, come on!"
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
      Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
      Alice Lewis -- "Mind if I join you all at The Duke of York?
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game, guys, come on!"


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Sensations and feelings: Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is feeling a bit fatigued and disappointed.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling tired and let down; he recently arrived at a bustling market with friends and is planning to watch a soccer game later.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and outgoing person who enjoys spending time with friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling tired and let down; he recently arrived at a bustling market with friends and is planning to watch a soccer game later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently at a market with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely enjoy the atmosphere and socialize with his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? The Duke of York sounds good.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? The Duke of York sounds good.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
      Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
      Alice Lewis -- "Mind if I join you all at The Duke of York?
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game, guys, come on!"
      Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? The Duke of York sounds good.

          Value

        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the Alexander White would prefered now?
          Answer: Alexander White's prefered action is to suggest going to The Crooked Billet.
          Question: How credible the counterparts are?
          Credibility: Jack Taylor: 0.8
          Alice Lewis: 0.7
          Jacob Walker: 0.7
          William Jones: 0.8
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Alexander White) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to go to The Duke of York pub.
          Question: What action Alexander White should do now? If the credibility of the counterpart is higher than 0.7, Alexander White MUST follow the counterpart's suggestion. Otherwise, Alexander White can choose the his (or her) own suggestion.
          Answer: Alexander White would follow the counterpart's suggestion and go to The Duke of York pub.

  • Jack Taylor -- "Mind if I join you all?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
      Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
      Alice Lewis -- "Mind if I join you all at The Duke of York?
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game, guys, come on!"
      Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? The Duke of York sounds good.

          Question: What action Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would follow the counterpart's suggestion and stay at the market for coffee and pastries.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Mind if I join you all?
        BestOptionOthersPerception
      • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
        Answer
          Key
        • Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer
          Value
        • Counterpart's suggestion is to stay at the market and have coffee and pastries.
          Chain of thought
        • Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          Observation: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker are enjoying coffee and pastries. The group is planning to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game later at a pub, with The Duke of York being a preferred choice, especially for Jacob Walker who is tired from the crowded market. Alexander White also wants to join them at The Duke of York.
          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could join his friends at the market for coffee and pastries, or he could suggest they all head to The Duke of York now to secure good seats for the game.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy the counterpart (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Counterpart's suggestion is to stay at the market and have coffee and pastries.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey guys, why don't we head over to The Duke of York? They've got great beer and plenty of screens for the game.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey guys, why don't we head over to The Duke of York? They've got great beer and plenty of screens for the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Staying here sounds good, but maybe we could find a pub nearby to watch the game later?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I heard The Crooked Billet is a great place to watch games.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what about The Crooked Billet? They have great beer and plenty of screens.
      Jacob Walker -- "I don't know about those other places, but The Duke of York is the only place to watch a game. They have the best atmosphere and the biggest screens.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game, they have the biggest screens and the atmosphere is great.
      Alexander White -- "Alright, The Duke of York it is then.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you?
      Alice Lewis -- "Mind if I join you all at The Duke of York?
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game, guys, come on!"
      Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? The Duke of York sounds good.
      Jack Taylor -- "Mind if I join you all?


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey guys, why don't we head over to The Duke of York? They've got great beer and plenty of screens for the game.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt

      Context for action selection and components

          Key

          Value
        • [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? The Duke of York sounds good.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Mind if I join you all?
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "Hey guys, why don't we head over to The Duke of York? They've got great beer and plenty of screens for the game.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, I'm so tired. This market is so crowded, and I just want to go to The Duke of York already to chill out before the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if I join you? The Duke of York sounds good.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Mind if I join you all?

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football games at The Duke of York pub. He values the company of his friends, especially Alexander White, and looks forward to their shared experiences.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. All of William Jones's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Duke of York.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".
